results.title: In partnership with the people
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Battery Point is one of the oldest parts of Hobart and the City Council is about to put into practice a development plan which will retain the character and charm of this area. Shows the signal station, the seamen’s cottages, the fine houses of the wealthy, Kelly’s Steps, St George’s Church and other historic items.

results.title: In parliament assembled
results.brief_description: The traditions and procedures of Britain’s Parliament. An introduction by Daniel Farson is followed by interviews with General Sir Brian Horrocks (Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod), Sir Edward Bridges (Secretary to Sir Winston Churchill’s wartime Cabinet), W.S. Morrison (then Speaker of the House of Commons) and three Members of Parliament representing the principal parties. Each discusses his own part in the procedures of Parliament.

results.title: In my name
results.brief_description: Shows the many new synagogues built in West Germany since the end of World War II. The inner architecture and arrangement of a synagogue is shown and explained.

results.title: In memoriam: Harold Holt
results.brief_description: On Sunday December 17th, 1967, Harold Holt, 18th Prime Minister of Australia, disappeared while swimming at Cheviot Beach near his holiday home at Portsea in Victoria. This film shows the memorial service held on December 22nd which was attended by many national leaders including President Johnson of the United States, and Prince Charles representing the Queen. Portrays the mood of a nation mourning the loss of a leader.

results.title: In harbour
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the many people who are engaged in working on Sydney Harbour - the fishermen who gain their livelihood from its waters, those who maintain its laws and ensure its cleanliness, those who maintain its equipment and preserve its many miles of wharves and those who dredge its bed and attend to its buoys. They keep the harbour for the ships from many lands to use, but themselves never go “outside”.

results.title: In good heart
results.creator_credit: Henry Cooper and Campbell Harper Films
results.brief_description: A description of the farming year in Scotland as seen in the lives of four farmers in the Border country, Ayrshire, the Highlands and Angus, and a reminder of the help received by farmers from various research institutes in their efforts to improve livestock and keep the land in the best possible condition.

results.title: In good company
results.creator_credit: Syd Wood, Frank Killian and Movietonenews
results.brief_description: Role and training in Australian Citizen Military Forces of part-time soldiers important in Australia’s defence; attendance at weekly parades, weekend bivouacs and annual camps where modern weapons, mock-up battles are used to provide realistic battle and trade experience. Army medical nurses, Women’s Royal Australian Army Corps, and Commandos learn bandaging, marching and boat-handling respectively as they train. Commentator: Kevin Golsby.

results.title: In dense traffic
results.creator_credit: John Edwards, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “How to Drive”.
Town driving demands great powers of concentration, road observation, the ability to react quickly to changing situations, and considerable driving skill. Patience and restraint play an important part in dense traffic driving, allowing safe distance around our vehicle as a ‘cushion of air’ and giving greater visibility of traffic movement ahead.

results.title: In case of emergency
results.brief_description: A look at the German Red Cross, the Technical Aid Movement and the Fire Brigade. These voluntary helpers, trained in their spare time, go abroad to assist in disasters.

results.title: In black and white
results.creator_credit: John Rawdon, Hindle Marriott Edgar, James Carr and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Presents paper as the mainstay of civilisation and as an instrument of immortality for the works of great men. Follows the development of paper-making from the production of single sheets by hand and then (early 19th century) by machine from rag-pulp. Perfected by an Englishman on the basis of a French invention, and fed by wood-pulp as suggested by the French scientist Reaumur a century before, this machine grew into the giant production lines seen at the close of the film.
